inference:
Solution:

The sum of the interior angles of a pentagon is $180(5-2) = 540^\circ$. Since $FGHIJ$ is a regular pentagon, each interior angle has measure $540^\circ/5 = 108^\circ$.  Therefore, $\angle FJI = 108^\circ$.

Angles $FJI$ and $AIJ$ are supplementary, so $\angle AIJ = 180^\circ - \angle FJI = 180^\circ - 108^\circ = 72^\circ$.

Similarly, $\angle FAJ = 72^\circ$.

Since the sum of the angles of triangle $FAJ$ is $180^\circ$, we have $\angle A = 180^\circ - \angle FAJ - \angle FAJ = 180^\circ - 72^\circ - 72^\circ = 36^\circ$.

Final Answer: $\boxed{36^\circ}$. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth: The sum of the angle measures in a pentagon is $180(5-2) = 540$ degrees, so each of the interior angles of regular pentagon $FGHIJ$ has measure $540^\circ / 5 = 108^\circ$.  Specifically, $\angle JFG = 108^\circ$, so \[\angle AFJ = 180^\circ - \angle JFG = 180^\circ - 108^\circ = 72^\circ.\]  Similarly, we have $\angle AJF = 180^\circ - 108^\circ = 72^\circ$.  Finally, the angles of $\triangle AFJ$ sum to $180^\circ$, so \[\angle FAJ = 180^\circ - \angle AFJ - \angle AJF = 180^\circ - 72^\circ - 72^\circ = \boxed{36^\circ}.\]
